title: Quiz 2: Infection Prevention & Control Basics
description: Covers the disease transmission cycle and standard precautions in a home setting.

questions.question: What is the term for micro-organisms that are normally present on skin and respiratory tracts and do not usually cause disease?
questions.explanation: Normal flora are micro-organisms found in specific areas of the body that do not cause disease unless introduced to a different area or the host is immunocompromised.
questions.hint: It implies something 'standard' or 'usual' to the body.

questions.question: In the context of HBC, how can infection be transmitted from a patient to a caregiver? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Splashing of infected body fluids on mucous membranes
Attending to a patient with open uncovered cuts

questions.explanation: Transmission occurs through contact with fluids, contaminated air, or entry points like cuts. Casual contact like talking does not typically transmit blood-borne pathogens.

questions.question: Plain soap and running water remove about ___BLANK___% of micro-organisms from hands.

richContent.content: Fact: Plain water alone removes only 50%.

questions.explanation: Plain water removes 50%, while soap removes 80-90% of micro-organisms.
questions.hint: It is a high percentage range between 70 and 100.

questions.question: Match the type of transmission to the preventive measure:
questions.explanation: Each transmission route requires a specific barrier or behavioral intervention.
questions.hint: Think about who is protecting whom.

questions.question: What is the recommended alternative if water is not available for hand washing in a home setting?

options.text: Wipe hands on a dry towel

questions.explanation: Alcohol hand rub (glycerine + alcohol) is the recommended alternative when water is unavailable.
questions.hint: A solution often found in hospitals.

questions.question: Double gloving (using two pairs of gloves) is recommended in home-based care for extra protection.
questions.explanation: The text states that the use of two pairs of gloves is NOT recommended because one may slip off and it is not cost-effective.

questions.question: Order the priority of infection prevention goals:
questions.explanation: While all are important, the primary focus begins with the patient and caregiver interaction, extending outward to family and community.
questions.hint: From the center of care outwards.

questions.question: What is the recommended duration for hand washing with plain soap and running water in a home care setting?
questions.explanation: 10-15 seconds is sufficient for hand washing with soap in the home environment.
questions.hint: It's slightly less than the time for a surgical scrub.

questions.question: Which of the following are appropriate times to wash hands? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Immediately after arriving at the patient's home
Only when hands are visibly soiled

questions.explanation: Hands must be washed before and after procedures/gloves and upon arrival/departure, regardless of visible soil.

questions.question: Standard precautions are called 'standard' because:

options.text: They are only for HIV patients
They should be followed routinely all the time for all patients
They are mandated by the government only

questions.explanation: Standard precautions apply to ALL patients at ALL times to minimize risk of infection.
